content: Ada Lovelace (1815-1852) was an analyst of Charles Babbage's analytical engine and is considered by many the 'first computer programmer'
Henrietta Swan Leavitt (1868-1921) joined the Harvard 'computers', a group of women engaged in the production of astronomical data at Harvard
Grete Hermann (1901-1984) published the foundational paper for computerized algebra
American women were recruited to do ballistics calculations and program computers during WWII
Women worked as WREN Colossus operators during WW2 at Bletchley Park
Many wives of scientists at Los Alamos were first organized as 'computers' on the Manhattan Project
Gertrude Blanch (1897-1996) led the Mathematical Tables Project group from 1938 to 1948
Betty Jennings, Betty Snyder, Frances Spence, Kay McNulty, Marlyn Wescoff, and Ruth Lichterman were the regularly working programmers of the ENIAC
Irma Wyman worked on a missile guidance project at the Willow Run Research Center
Kathleen Booth (1922-) is credited with writing the assembly language for the ARC2 computer
Grace Hopper (1906-1992), was a United States Navy officer and one of the first programmers of the Harvard Mark I, known as the 'Mother of COBOL'
Evelyn Boyd Granville (1924-) was the second African-American woman in the US to receive a PhD in mathematics
Ida Rhodes (1900-1986) was one of the pioneers in the analysis of systems of programming
Mary Coombs (1929-) was one of the first programmers on, and was the first female programmer on LEO, the first business computer
Orbital calculations for the United States' Explorer 1 satellite were solved by the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory's all-female 'computers', many of whom were recruited out of high school
Dana Ulery (1938-), was the first female engineer at Jet Propulsion Laboratory, developing real-time tracking systems using a North American Aviation Recomp II, a 40-bit word size computer
Jean E Sammet (1928-2017), developed the FORMAC programming language
Dame Stephanie 'Steve' Shirley (1933-), founded the UK software company FI
Joan Ball was the first person to start a computer dating service in 1964
Mary Allen Wilkes (1937-) was the first person to use a computer in a private home (in 1965) and the first developer of an operating system (LAP) for the first minicomputer (LINC)
Sister Mary Kenneth Keller (1913-1985) became the first American woman to earn a Ph D
Margaret R Fox (1916-2006) was appointed Chief of the Office of Computer Information in 1966, part of the Institute for Computer Science and Technology of NBS
Vera Moln-r (1924-) is one of the pioneers of computer and algorithmic arts
Margaret Hamilton (1936-) was in late 1960s Director of the Software Engineering Division of the MIT Instrumentation Laboratory, which developed on-board flight software for the Apollo space program
Erna Schneider Hoover (1926-) is an American mathematician notable for inventing a computerized telephone switching method which developed modern communication according to several reports
Margaret Burnett (computer scientist) (1949-) became the first woman software developer ever hired by Procter & Gamble (Ivorydale), a 13,000-employee complex that included their R&D center
Mary Shaw (1943-) became the first woman to earn a Ph D in Computer Science from Carnegie Mellon University
Adele Goldberg (1945-), was one of developers of the Smalltalk language
Karen Sp-rck Jones (1935-2007), was one of the pioneers of information retrieval and natural language processing
Sandra Kurtzig founded ASK Computer Systems, an early Silicon Valley startup
Susan Nycum co-authored Computer Abuse, a minor classic that was one of the first studies to define and document computer-related crime
Phyllis Fox (1923-) worked on the PORT portable mathematical-numerical library
Elizabeth Feinler (1931-) and her team defined a simple text file format for Internet host names
Irene Greif became the first woman to earn a Ph D in computer science from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Sophie Wilson (1957-), is a British computer scientist
Carol Shaw (1955-), was a game designer and programmer for Atari Corp and Activision
Carla Meninsky was the game designer and programmer for Atari 2600 games Dodge 'Em and Warlords
Lorinda Cherry worked on the Writer's Workbench (wwb) for Bell Labs
Janese Swanson (1958-) (with others) developed the first of the Carmen Sandiego games
Roberta Williams (1953-), did pioneering work in graphical adventure games for personal computers, particularly the King's Quest series
Susan Kare (1954-), created the icons and many of the interface elements for the original Apple Macintosh in the 1980s
Radia Perlman (1951-), invented the Spanning Tree Protocol
Irma Wyman (1927-), was the first Honeywell CIO
Monica S Lam receives a Ph D for her work on optimising compilers
-va Tardos (1957-), was the recipient of the Fulkerson Prize for her research on design and analysis of algorithms
Frances E Allen (1932-), became the first female IBM Fellow in 1989
Frances Brazier, professor of Computer Science at the Vrije Universiteit in Amsterdam, is one of the founder of NLnet, the first Internet service provider in the Netherlands

Donna Dubinsky (1955-), CEO and co-founder of Palm, Inc, co-founder of Handspring, co-founder of Numenta, Harvard Business School's Alumni Achievement Award winner for 'introducing the first successful personal digital assistant (PDA) and who is now developing a computer memory system modeled after the human brain'

Shafi Goldwasser (1958-), a theoretical computer scientist, is a two-time recipient of the G-del Prize for research on complexity theory, cryptography and computational number theory, and the invention of zero-knowledge proofs
Barbara Liskov(1939-), together with Jeannette Wing, developed the Liskov substitution principle
Sally Floyd (1953-), is known for her work on Transmission Control Protocol
Xiaoyuan Tu (1967-), was the first female recipient of ACM's Doctoral Dissertation Award
Anita Borg (1949-2003), was the founding director of the Institute for Women and Technology (IWT), renamed Anita Borg Institute (ABI) in her honor in 2003
LinuxChix an international organization for women who use Linux and women and men who want to support women in computing was founded by Deb Richardson
Marissa Mayer (1975-), was the first female engineer hired at Google, and was later named Vice President of Search Product and User Experience
Ellen Spertus earned a PhD in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science from MIT in 1998 with the notable thesis 'ParaSite: Mining the structural information on the World-Wide Web'
Jeri Ellsworth (1974-), is a self-taught computer chip designer and creator of the C64 Direct-to-TV
Lucy Sanders (1954-) co-founded the National Center for Women & Information Technology
Audrey Tang (1981-), was the initiator and leader of the Pugs project
Mary Lou Jepsen (1965-), was the founder and chief technology officer of One Laptop Per Child (OLPC), and the founder of Pixel Qi
Maria Klawe (1951-), was the first woman to become President of the Harvey Mudd College since its founding in 1955 and was ACM president from 2002 until 2004
Melanie Rieback's research concerns the security and privacy of Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology, she is known to have programmed the first virus to infect RFID devices
Joanna Rutkowska presented Blue Pill, a rootkit based on x86 virtualization, at the Black Hat Briefings computer security conference
Megan Smith named third (and first female) Chief Technology Officer of the United States of America (USCTO), succeeding Todd Park
